p: Our study demonstrates that the flowers of both species produce sesquiterpenes and monoterpenes as primary volatile components of their fragrance, like most of the angiosperms that contain osmophores ( Metcalf and Kogan 1987; Knudsen et al. 2006 ). The fragrance is dominated by sesquiterpenes in A. humile, especially β-caryophyllene, and, as previously reported by Wang et al. (2010) , monoterpenes, especially terpinolene, in M. indica. The same types of substances are also identified as main components of essential oils in fruits and leaves of both species. However, in these organs, the predominant sesquiterpenes in A. humile are α-bulnesene and γ-cadinene ( Cardoso et al. 2010 ; Winck et al. 2010 ), and in leaves of M. indica the principal monoterpene is cyperene ( Gebara et al. 2011 ).
